This period marks the transition of several key pieces from royal families to public institutions, establishing the foundation of the Louvre’s collection of imperial jewels.

keyTakeAways: The theft of nine high-value artifacts from the Louvre's Apollo Gallery in Paris on October 20, 2025, is described as a 'national disaster' due to the historical and symbolic value of the items.

The items stolen include a sapphire diadem, emerald necklace and earrings gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces belonging to Empress Eugénie, including a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch.
One key item, Empress Eugénie’s crown, was attempted to be stolen but was recovered near the scene, though it was damaged during the heist.
The jewelry has deep historical roots, with origins tied to Napoleon, Marie Antoinette, and Empress Eugénie, and some items were once owned by royal families before being passed through generations.
The stolen items were crafted by prominent 19th-century Parisian jewelers and reflect the artistry and craftsmanship of early French royal jewelry.
Experts believe the thieves may have dismantled the items to melt down the gold and silver, indicating a possible motive of financial gain over cultural preservation.
The Louvre acquired several of these items through historic sales or inheritance, including the emerald necklace in 2004 for €3.7 million and the brooch in 2008 for €6.72 million.
The loss of these artifacts is seen as a major blow to France’s national pride and cultural identity, as they represent the legacy of French emperors and queens.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 20, 2025, a group of thieves carried out a seven-minute heist at the Louvre Museum’s Apollo Gallery, targeting high-value royal jewelry including a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces from Empress Eugénie’s collection. The items were crafted by renowned 19th-century jewelers and represent deep historical and cultural ties to French monarchy. Among the stolen pieces, one of Eugénie’s crowns was recovered near the scene, though damaged. Experts, including art recovery specialist Arthur Brand, describe the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the irreplaceable value of these artifacts, which symbolize France’s imperial past and national pride. The jewelry has passed through generations and institutions, including the Orléans family and Van Cleef & Arpels, before being acquired by the Louvre in the 20th century. The loss is seen as a serious blow to cultural heritage, with suspects believed to have dismantled and sold the items to maximize financial gain.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
